summary: The Unfinished Swan on the PlayStation 4 is a pretty game made prettier, and a gentle charmer in its own right.
Depth's underwater twist on a familiar design comes up all wet.
NBA Live 15 is a step in the right direction, but that still doesn’t make it a good basketball game.
WWE 2K15's last-gen outing is a sad afterthought at the end of a console era.
Gabriel Knight returns with a modern twist, bringing with him the good and the bad.
Sledgehammer Games lays the groundwork for more futuristic Call of Duty games with a comprehensive multiplayer experience and a faulty but stimulating campaign.
The NES Remix series finds the perfect home on 3DS.
Football Manager 2015 is the same game we've come to know and love, but in this case that's no bad thing.
Dungeon of the Endless blends many different gameplay styles into a satisfying dungeon crawler.
It may be souped-up fast and super tough, but Planetary Annihilation still hooks you with intense combat and brilliant enemy AI.
Dreamfall Chapters' first entry isn't wholly satisfying on its own, but it lays a great and characterful foundation for the episodes to come.
Fun villains and a joyful campaign make Trap Team another delightful entry into the Skylanders series.
Heidi is a huge fan of JRPGs, and is always eager to see new entries in the genre get localized and released in the West. While Fairy Fencer F was ...
Minecraft: Xbox One Edition lays the foundation for incredible constructions and grand adventures, both large and small.
Satisfying combat and a darkly beautiful, interconnected kingdom make Lords of the Fallen more than just a clone.
Sunset Overdrive doesn't take itself too seriously, and it's bursting at the seams with colorful action and creativity.
Legend of Grimrock II is another fantastic trip to the grid.
Neverending Nightmares is an apt name for an unnerving but meandering experience.
Civilization: Beyond Earth's brave new world feels pretty familiar, but that's okay.
The Evil Within is a captivating return to the glory days of survival horror whose various issues keep it just short of greatness.
F1 2014 does little different to last year's game, but fans will dig the great handling and new season of cars.
A City Sleeps is a great looking shooter with compelling mechanics, but it suffers under the weight of its ambitions and prohibitive difficulty.
This top-down arena shooter runs afoul of fun.
The Legend of Korra doesn't even come close to capturing the spark of the universe it depicts.
Fantasia is an excellent and joyful game that turns rhythm gameplay into performance art.
Falling Skies is a functional, unattractive, and uninspired XCOM clone.
TRI: Of Friendship and Madness redefines the first-person puzzler through creative simplicity.
One of the best games of 2012 gets a mild makeover.
Short Peace's four animated shorts are wonderful examples of modern animation, but the game portion, Ranko Tsukigime's Longest Day, is a letdown on almost every front.
Hack 'n' Slash's puzzles esoteric puzzles are alternately delightful and discouraging.
Costume Quest 2 is a charming sequel that fixes most of its predecessor's flaws, though it remains a very short, overly simple experience.
Fantasy Life is an ambitious but repetitive RPG that makes fails to make the mundane magical.
Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel brings you more of the loot and lighthearted humor you love, though it never quite overcomes the gravity of its predecessors.
Bayonetta 2 is a classic in the making, and one of the finest, most wonderfully insane action games ever made.
Endless Legend adds fantastic twists to familiar strategy.
Ryse: Son of Rome is a repetitive and tedious homage to the gruesome battles showcased in the film 300.
Dark Souls II, in all its epic designs, fittingly concludes in the harshness of winter.
All-new game mechanics, first-rate graphics, and involved sleuthing make Sherlock Holmes: Crimes & Punishments a great adventure game.
NBA 2K15’s overhauled movement system and improved shooting mechanics make it the best-playing basketball game in existence.
Clunky combat, bad AI, and so-so stealth leave Styx lingering in the shadows of mediocrity.
Driveclub is a solid, basic racing game with lots of tracks, lots of cars, and very little in the way of personality.
Persona 4 Ultimax is a worthy upgrade to a solid fighter, with plenty of new content for competitive players and Persona fans alike.
Chuck E. Scream.
There's a party in Forza Horizon 2, and everyone's invited.
Alien: Isolation harbors legitimate frights, but they're nestled between endless stretches of bland lever-pulling and button-pressing.
Stronghold Crusader 2 brings smart army strategy, but squanders its most interesting asset: the castle.
Spacecom hovers between minimalist and incomplete.
An old-fashioned game in a newfangled era, Gauntlet does too much and too little all at once.
The Vanishing of Ethan Carter is a beautiful adventure that slowly unravels its superficial veneer to reveal a touching and personal story.
Fenix Rage is sadistic platformer that tests your skills, and, sometimes, your sanity.
A finely-made Watch Dogs quasi-epilogue finds a new playable protagonist struggling to tie loose ends
It's scary and has some great ideas, but Kraven Manor doesn't live up to its potential.
Smash Bros. is a cavalcade of cartoonish violence and chaos, and it's never been better.
Shadow of Mordor's political machinations and rambunctious action make it a cut above your everyday Lord of the Rings game.
Minecraft: PlayStation 4 Edition is a sandbox gem, and one of the best games to own for PlayStation 4.
Wasteland 2 is an intricate and triumphant return of a role-playing classic.
FIFA 15 might not be wholly realistic, but it brings more flair and excitement than any game in the series so far.
Natural Doctrine takes strategy role-playing games one step forward, and several clumsy steps back.
D4 is all kinds of crazy, and you may not take to its unique brand of humor. But if you do, there's no forgetting it.
Cannon Brawl finds the tools it needs but doesn't know what to do with them.
Neverwinter now offers more classes and zones than ever before, but combat still outshines every other aspect.
Roundabout's story is short-lived, but it's jam-packed with humor and crazy, quirky action.
The Toy Box is back and better than ever in Disney Infinity 2.0, and it's still a great way to have a shared gameplay experience with the favorite little child ...
An unlikely pairing of Dynasty Warriors and The Legend Of Zelda yields greatly satisfying results.
Its core combat is sensational, but Lichdom: Battlemage never evolves a proper game around it.
Minimum puts a fresh and exciting spin on the online arena.
Murasaki Baby is a visual treat, even if all the hand-holding detracts from what's taking place on screen.
Hatoful Boyfriend is a bizarre, surprising, and unforgettable journey into the world of literal lovebirds.
Destiny's essentials are there, and they're great--but the game surrounding them is cold and shallow.
Theatrhythm Final Fantasy: Curtain Call is a massive dose of nostalgia for Final Fantasy fans, and even though it's very similar to its predecessor, there are plenty of reasons to ...
The Sims 4 is beautiful and charming, but its constricted structure makes it disappointingly limited.
New generation graphics and marginal gameplay improvements clash with a lot of missing features in NHL 15.
Dead Rising 3 combines bland gameplay and colorful stereotypes into one unfortunate adventure.
Dance Central Spotlight is a lean but thoroughly enjoyably sequel that shifts its focus toward the core dancing experience.
The Last Tinker’s colorful art style isn’t enough to overcome its tired mechanics and dreadful framerate.
Velocity balances platforming and shoot-em-ups as well as modern aesthetics and retro play to create a nearly perfect action experience
Gunvolt is an inventive and fast-paced twist on the Mega Man formula that will keep you riveted to your 3DS while the ride lasts.
A splendid second DLC for Dark Souls II offers an insightful visual history lesson without saying a word.
A brutal showdown and zombies on ice mark the final, oddly slow-paced, episode of season two of The Walking Dead.
Madden 15 is a beautiful football game, but its biggest achievement stems from much improved defensive mechanics that make both sides of the ball fun to play.
Firefall's shooter/MMORPG hybrid combines genres to produce mediocrity.
Infamous: First Light benefits from Second Son's excellent fundamentals. Its missions and storytelling, however, lack spark.
Memorable characters, sharp writing and engaging mystery-solving gameplay make this deadly island adventure a trip to remember.
Golf returns to the PC with The Golf Club, a rigorous simulation that falls just short of the green.
Duel of Champions is the most epic card game you've already played.
It doesn't move the genre forward in any way, but Shadowgate is a wonderful return to the early days of adventuring.
CounterSpy is short, but its stylized presentation and alluring gameplay hooks make it too sweet to pass up.
The PS4 port of the hilariously macabre PC game could do with a few operations of its own.
Even if you can tolerate the inane stripping mechanic, Akiba's Trip does little with its battle system or narrative to warrant your time.
Metro Redux is a terrific package that combines two bleak games into a single cohesive whole.
The Path to Thalamus is not free of bumps, but the journey should be taken, if only because the sights are so vivid.
Console owners reap the benefits of two years worth of changes and updates in this conclusive version of Diablo III.
Like it's predecessors, Risen 3 provides a rollicking adventure that doesn't quite deliver on the details.
The lack of direction can lead to repeated frustrations, but the striking visuals and hypnotic character movement make Hohokum a joy.
Tedium is at the heart of Sacred 3, a successor to the earlier games in the series in name only.
This repackaging of the classic Wii Sports drops the ball when it comes to connectivity.
Halfway is an emotional tale of mystery and survival that occasionally lacks the courage of its own convictions.
Road Not Taken treads an unconventional trail, and is mostly better for it.
Metrico hits a few high notes, but fails to stay on key throughout its brief performance.
Magic 2015 gives you fewer reasons to love a fantastic game.
Great exploration and combat make Rogue Legacy a game you will want to play (and die in) over and over again.
Its conclusion may be putrid, but Only If's primary redeeming feature is that it does eventually end.
Emotional storytelling and challenging gameplay can't wholly save Gods Will Be Watching from some of its bad design choices.
While it's just a charming Breakout clone on the surface, Siesta Fiesta has enough tricks to make it something you don't want to sleep through.
The Last of Us Remastered is a spruced-up edition of one of the most well-crafted action adventure games of the last console generation.
Lengthy quests and catchy tactical combat are at the black heart of King's Bounty: Dark Side.
Crown of the Sunken King sets an effective tone for Dark Souls II's Lost Crowns trilogy with inventive environments and fearsome new foes.
The most fragile hero of side-scrolling platforming returns in a beautiful reimagining of Abe's Oddysee.
Super Comboman fuses platforming, action, and fighting into a single failure.
Unrest is an unconventional but erratic adventure game that inspires empathy even as it undercuts its own message.
Clementine is no longer a spectator in Amid the Ruins, the action-packed latest episode in season two of The Walking Dead.
A host of glitches keep Wayward Manor feeling anything but welcoming.
A cheesy puzzler with plenty of charm, MouseCraft favors style over substance.
The excellent Divinity: Original Sin isn't a look into the history of role-playing games, but instead a look into their future.
It tries to add something new with its story mode, but Infinity Runner isn't much more than a rote Temple Run clone.
Sniper Elite III can be a chore, but its gleeful X-ray kills help make up for its deficiencies.
Smooth and exciting aerial and tank action is at the heart of War Thunder, a big and broad multiplayer excursion back to World War II.
Cry Wolf brings The Wolf Among Us to an uneven conclusion, but still packs the occasional emotional punch.
Strong writing isn't enough to establish the apocalyptic stakes at play in Richard & Alice.
Child of Light is a wonderful fairy tale of a game, with a gorgeous and imaginative realm to explore and a melancholy story at its heart.
Spoiler Alert's reverse platforming isn't a strong enough gimmick to make it worth bothering with.
Xenonauts is an excellent strategy game that casts you as Earth's only line of defense against an apparently omnipresent extraterrestrial threat.
Offering no more than meets the eye, Transformers: Rise of the Dark Spark is just a shallow, frustrating, and incoherent third-person shooter.
Ace Combat Infinity casts a cynical eye at its own pedigree, but some vestiges of joy remain.
WildStar is a colorful and traditional online role-playing game that evokes the compulsive need to fight everything you can fight, and click everything you can click.
Killzone: Shadow Fall Intercept's mishmash of co-op ideas doesn't make for the most compelling of experiences.
Shovel Knight recalls, but doesn't rely on, many greats from gaming's past, but lacks the inventive spark that could have elevated it to classic territory.
Solid puzzling and catchy tunes back up Magical Beat, but a dearth of content stops the show prematurely.
EA Sports UFC looks almost as good as a real MMA fight, but poorly balanced systems dull the excitement.
Blood of the Werewolf has never been better than on the Xbox 360, offering improved platforming and refined pacing.
The blob is back, but his adventure stumbles.
With beautiful art, a sentimental story, and gameplay that emphasizes helping people rather than killing them, Valiant Hearts: The Great War is a refreshingly different kind of war game.
Grid Autosport is often too ambitious for its own good, resulting in a diverse but inconsistent racer.
For a fan of the series, The Elder Scrolls Online makes for a pleasant return to Tamriel. It's just not a terribly great MMO.
Nether's dire world can be immersive, but glaring issues ranging from unbalanced mechanics to glitches prevent you from getting swept away.
Anomaly Defenders ditches the series' prior innovations for something more familiar and far less thrilling.
Repetitious play, shallow mechanics, and squandered potential all make Hegemony Rome a mediocre experience.
Britton Peele is a fan of both ancient mythology and puzzle games, but Munin wasn't the chocolate and peanut butter combo he was hoping for. He solved all of Munin's ...
Super Dead Rising 3 Arcade Remix is a fun, nostalgia-fueled romp through Capcom's history.
The wartime journey of a gun-wielding news reporter is fraught with Nazi aggression, poor game design, frustrating glitches, and an unconvincing message of rebellion.
The alleys of Always Sometimes Monsters hide both trash and treasure alike
Comforting colors, excellent sound design, and simple gameplay make Entwined a lovely and fleeting experience.
1001 Spikes will kill you, but it does so in a way that's both fair and fun.
Space Run is an exciting tower defense game in which you rocket through the galaxy at warp speed.
Borderlands 2 on the Vita preserves the lion's share of the game's significant appeal despite some shortcomings.
Destructive mayhem and revenge fantasies are at the heart of Kill the Bad Guy, a lightweight but engaging puzzler.
Tomodachi Life brings the quirk in spades, but it's not long before the novelty wears off.
Mind Zero's attempts to mimic a proven success are foiled by a dull story and plodding, aggravating gameplay.
It's easy to be overwhelmed by the many problems in Murdered: Soul Suspect, but if you dig a little deeper, there's an interesting story to uncover.
Pushmo World's colorful conundrums are a pleasant and absorbing way to occupy your brain.
Ultra Street Fighter IV brings with it five new characters, four new stages, three new game mechanics, and a whole host of other changes that make it the definitive Street ...
Glitches and a dire lack of puzzle variation keep Project Temporality from being time well spent.
Among the Sleep makes good use of its unusual concept, taking you on a distinctive journey through the frightening dreams of a young child.
A clever twist on puzzle platforming, Where Is My Heart knows to end before it gets tiresome.
The Incredible Adventures of Van Helsing II taps the spirit of classic action role-playing games and delivers a great combat system and an exciting world.
Air Control is 30 minutes worth of horrific, broken nonsense.
It's technically awkward, hard to look at, and sometimes tedious to play. But Drakengard 3's distinctly strange and fascinating world, characters, and structure make it a one-of-a-kind experience.
In Sheep's Clothing continues A Wolf Among Us' intriguing and violent story, with only a bit of wheel-spinning to slow it down.
Watch Dogs' attempts to say something serious are overshadowed by how enormously fun it is to create chaos in its impressive open world.
Monochroma wastes its gripping premise and eye-catching visual design by having clunky controls and a wealth of inconsistencies.
Tropico 5's irreverent wit and smooth difficulty curve make governing your own banana republic an easy and enjoyable experience.
Warlock 2 is a strong sequel that deftly builds on the solid foundation of its predecessor. Unfortunately, not all of its ideas are fully realized.
With a gorgeous audiovisual style, unconventional science fiction narrative, and empowering combat system, Transistor is a distinctive and memorable experience.
Minecraft: PlayStation 3 Edition provides the core gameplay experience you're looking for, though it takes a few steps back from the PC version.
In the Nazi-dominated alternate history of 1960, it takes more than big guns to topple this new regime.
It has lofty goals as a globe-trotting mystery, but Memento Mori 2 is a poor localization of a poor adventure game.
For all its slick flourishes, this intriguing sword-dueling game could still use a lot of sharpening.
If the foxes in Nutjitsu want those mystic acorns so much, they can keep them.
Mario Kart 8 shifts its focus from chaotic weapons to precise driving, and that makes this one of the most rewarding entries in the series.
Sir, You Are Being Hunted doesn't execute on the premise in its own name.
Clementine's soul and skin are in peril in In Harm's Way, this season's most harrowing episode yet of The Walking Dead.
Super Time Force gleefully shreds conventional concepts of time travel in both its writing and gameplay, making it a refreshing twist on the side-scrolling shooter.
Dark Souls II can be tedious and unwelcoming for someone who hasn't already come to terms with the series.
Bound by Flame is a rickety role-playing game that bites off far more than it can chew.
Kentucky Route Zero: Act III is the boldest, most extraordinary chapter yet in this transcendent American road journey.
When it comes to blowing up military monstrosities, no game does it better than World of Tanks.
Titanfall mixes parkour and mechs for a competitive shooter that will entice even the most jaded player back onto the battlefield.
Sportsfriends' simple games provide some of the best local multiplayer you and a few friends can have.
Final Fantasy XIV is reborn on the PlayStation 4, rife with new features and gorgeous visuals that will tempt PC and PlayStation 3 players all over again.
Grand Theft Auto Online is both exhilarating and infuriating, often at the same time, and a lack of structure makes your criminal exploits feel kind of meaningless.
JoJo's Bizarre Adventure: All Star Battle faithfully captures the extreme personality of its source material, but the game itself is more style than substance.
The Amazing Spider-Man 2 is as fun as it is flawed, capturing the snarky joy of the webbed crusader amid the repetition of combat and tedious side quests.
Don't be afraid of the dark in the shallow and cliched horror adventure Daylight.
Fract OSC's chorus soars, but its verse languishes.
Child of Light is a singular adventure that embraces sadness in a beautiful, affecting way.
Kirby: Triple Deluxe is a wildly inventive and colorful platformer that makes great use of 3D.
Mario Golf: World Tour is built upon strong mechanics, but too often relies on novelty value.
The Elder Scrolls Online immerses you in its intricate quests and fantasy landscapes, only to undercut its strengths at every turn.
Cold, Cold Heart fumbles its ending, but benefits from a solid narrative foundation and a strong sense of momentum.
Broken Sword 5: The Serpent's Curse's second half charms and delights, but glitches and a more linear focus tarnish the overall delivery.
NES Remix is a fun way to remind yourself to play through the classics again.
Demon Gaze's unique battle elements and engaging first-person exploration make it a solid, enjoyable dungeon crawler.
Sir Hammerlock vs. the Son of Crawmerax ends the story of Borderlands 2 on a great note, providing a beautiful new location to explore, tough enemies, and loads of humor.
Life Goes On is a great, morbid puzzler that reminds you that there is no victory without sacrifice.
Trials Fusion delivers the same exciting racing action from previous games, with a beautiful new aesthetic and enough humor to keep you laughing.
More than a cynical cash-in, 2014 FIFA World Cup's worth comes from the depth of its key game modes.
Conception II has plenty of lust, but it lacks heart.
Moebius: Empire Rising is a short adventure bogged down by dull characters and tedious puzzle solving.
Lego The Hobbit is charming, funny, faithful to the films, and incredibly tedious to play.
The Director's Cut version of last year's Strike Suit Zero is periodically entertaining, but clogged up with too much repetition and an unconvincing Transformer ship gimmick.
Ultra-fast-paced RPG gameplay, delightful parodies, and a wealth of new features make Half-Minute Hero: The Second Coming a blast to play.
SimCity may finally be playable offline, but all of its flaws are just as evident now as they were before.
Mercenary Kings heads down several familiar paths at once, to mixed results.
The Wolf Among Us hits its stride with an electrifying third installment.
PlanetSide 2 is war, plain and simple.
Ragnarok Odyssey returns to the hunt with some new tricks tucked into its armor, along with some old irritants.
Kinect Sports Rivals is an uneven collection of sports-themed minigames that won't hold your interest for long.
Arma III's new campaign isn't going to win hearts and minds, but its creation suite stands strong.
Lightning Returns proves to be a poor point of entry for a Final Fantasy newcomer despite its thorough explanations and extensive exposition.
MLB 14: The Show delivers a fast, tight, great-looking game of baseball.
The PC port of last year's iPad prequel to Deus Ex: Human Revolution could do with a few augmentations.
The colorless world of Betrayer is home to an intriguing mystery, tense atmosphere, and inconsistent enemies.
It's not especially unique, but well-designed puzzles make Escape Goat 2 a lot of fun.
Alucard's tale in Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 - Revelations DLC falls flat, and there are too few combat sequences to get the most out of his unique skill set.
Much more than a pretty role-playing game, Final Fantasy X/X-2 HD Remaster is an excellent collection of two PlayStation 2 classics.
The Age of Wonders series returns with a fun and dynamic turn-based strategy game that plants its focus squarely on creating exciting battles.
The excellent Burial at Sea - Episode 2 marks a welcome return to form for BioShock Infinite.
Reaper of Souls brings great new campaign content to Diablo III while also giving you tantalizing reasons to revisit the places you've already been.
There's some meaty, complex gameplay to The Witch and the Hundred Knight, but you'll need to endure a terrible lead character and a plodding opening stretch to make it that ...
Smite puts the powers of the gods in your hands as you engage in a battle that will rattle the heavens.
Dragons and Titans is a halfhearted and frustrating online arena that doesn't deserve your time.
The gorgeous world of Infamous: Second Son is brimming with delights, setting you loose in Seattle to partake in fast-paced, inventive combat that's an absolute blast.
Hearthstone is a free-to-play collectible card game that embraces new players through its presentation and simplicity and satisfies veterans with complex strategies hidden between the lines.
Less crossover and more combination, the excellent Professor Layton vs. Phoenix Wright: Ace Attorney provides each of its stars equal face time.
Significant changes to the loot system in a recent patch make Diablo III a more rewarding game than it's ever been.
Scattershot action and awful writing make Yaiba: Ninja Gaiden Z one lifeless zombie invasion.
Luftrausers' arcadelike simplicity makes conquering the skies feel natural and fun.
Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes has a brief narrative, but its short length is bolstered by flexible side missions and exceptional replayability.
The Yawhg is a fine board-game-inspired diversion for a spell of rain, but don't expect to wait out a long storm with it.
Yoshi's New Island lacks the imagination that made its progenitor beloved, instead offering a slow-paced adventure that's too easy for its own good.
The sloppy action of Dragon Ball Z: Battle of Z makes it a particularly poor entry in the long line of Dragon Ball Z games.
This innovative alien bug-blasting indie real-time strategy game proves that fun runs deeper than meets the eye.
Fantastic atmosphere and stellar writing make Shadowrun: Dragonfall a great adaptation of its cyberpunk source material.
Dark Souls II is a terrific sequel and an amazing game in its own right, making every peek into the unknown a gut-wrenching thrill.
Exhilarating player movement and a brilliant blend of two distinct combat styles make Titanfall a thrilling shooter.
Towerfall Ascension is a fast and frantic multiplayer game that provides lots of interesting variations on its enjoyable archery combat--just make sure you have a few friends on hand to ...
The world of NaissanceE is mysterious, hostile, and starkly beautiful.
Season Two of The Walking Dead starts coming together in the bleak and harrowing second episode, A House Divided.
South Park: The Stick of Truth is as simplistic as role-playing games come, but it captures the spirit of the animated show's riotous raunch.
Basement Crawl tries to emulate Bomberman with a horror setting, but fails to ignite on all accounts.
Resident Evil 4 finally gets the PC version it always deserved, with only a few visual stumbles to detract from its brilliance.
Slow and strategic tank battles bring a different kind of fun to the fight in World of Tanks' multiplayer armored combat.
Banished is a clever network of interlocking systems and mechanics that accomplish a lot with very little.
Rambo: The Video game is a fun, simple rail shooter.
The gameplay of Plants vs. Zombies: Garden Warfare is standard stuff, but the game's lighthearted tone makes it an appealing multiplayer shooter that stands out from the crowd.
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow 2 starts off with a whimper, but the gripping second half of the game makes plodding through a few hours of tedium a worthwhile chore in ...
At its best, Thief makes you feel like a devious outlaw. Sadly, such moments are too few.
Dustforce is a delightful game that mixes its tranquil world with some seriously tough platforming.
Earth Defense Force 2025 is shallow and unattractive. It's also good, mindless, destructive fun.
Journal has a compelling vibe, but disjointed storytelling gets in the way of what it has to say.
Horizon is a strange, clumsy, and compelling composite of ideas and mechanics from many different games.
Toukiden: The Age of Demons duplicates the appeal of the Monster Hunter games while also establishing its own identity.
Strider is a high-speed, acrobatic action game with a hero that’s fun to control from the first blade swipe to the final deathblow.
The Castle Doctrine is a poorly balanced structure built on an unstable foundation.
Donkey Kong Country: Tropical Freeze's unimaginative level design saps the fun out of this retro-inspired platformer.
TxK is totally Tempest, but it's some of the best dang Tempest you can play.
The Last of Us: Left Behind offers an endearing look at Ellie's life before she met Joel, delivering a heartfelt story that makes an excellent character even more sympathetic.
Loads of humor and outrageousness make this cyberpunk indie adventure worth playing.
Loadout's deep weapon-crafting system and outrageous violence make for boisterous fun.
Outlast loses momentum occasionally, but its unsettling atmosphere and pulse-pounding chases keep pulling you along for the ride.
Galactic Starfighter serves up a richly featured expansion of The Old Republic's previously bare-bones space combat experience.
Danganronpa: Trigger Happy Havoc presents a fascinating look at the human experience, using smart storytelling to invest you in this dark and creepy world.
Lightning Returns is a jumble of mechanics and story elements that don't mesh into a meaningful whole.
The Lego Movie Videogame re-creates and expands on most of the film's greatest moments.
Strike Vector needs refinement, but there's a promising foundation holding up its hybridized combat.
Not every element of Fable Anniversary holds up against its contemporaries, but it's an amusing and charming return to one of gaming's most delightful worlds.
The Wolf Among Us: Episode 2 - Smoke and Mirrors is another engrossing chapter in this ongoing saga, though it doesn't blaze as brightly as the introductory episode.
Octodad: Dadliest Catch has moments of comic brilliance, but much of it is uninspired, and it ends before it really even gets going.
Rekoil harks back to online shooters of old, but game-breaking problems keep it from hitting its mark.
Echo Prime offers a flawed but accessible mix of repetitive action and customization.
Team Fortress 2 is an inspiring example of how great design and passionate players can keep a competitive game lively years after release.
Impressive visual flair cannot overcome the shallow core gameplay that plagues Ultimate Ninja Storm 3 Full Burst.
No-frills realism and tight teamwork make Insurgency a welcome break from the status quo.
Tomb Raider: Definitive Edition is as exciting as it is gorgeous, offering a robust adventure that satisfies on almost every front.
Might & Magic X: Legacy seems like a 15-year-old leftover, for better and for worse.
Ubisoft takes a former 5-inch Assassin's Creed adventure to much larger screens and brings its baggage along with it.
In OlliOlli, over-the-top skateboarding gets boiled down to a high-score chase that is difficult to master but intensely rewarding.
It isn't its horror but rather its humanity that makes The Cat Lady such a worthwhile journey.
Pandora: First Contact looks to the stars, but it can't even achieve escape velocity.
Blackguards is a grueling tactical role-playing game that thrives on brutal challenges.
Consortium is a fun story-driven sci-fi role-playing game with some first-person shooter elements, but bugs and glitches mar the experience.
Nidhogg isn't too satisfying alone, but it offers frantically enjoyable sword-dueling action with local friends.
This brutal survival and crafting adventure delivers fun and punishment in equal measure.
Frozen Hearth doesn't offer anything that wasn't done better elsewhere, and long ago.
Dr. Luigi repackages the Dr. Mario formula with some new ideas, but limited options and slow pacing leave it feeling anemic.
The opening act for Broken Age establishes a wonderfully vibrant world with a surprisingly somber tone. Hopefully, it will all pay off in the second act.
A serviceable survival horror, Dementium II was better with a stylus.
More often than not, the gorgeous and intriguing Banner Saga successfully balances the conflicting ideas of strategic control and arbitrary consequence.
Continue?9876543210 explores what happens to video game characters after the game-over screen fades, and in turn asks how we'll face our own mortality.
Driftmoon is a simple role-playing game that enraptures with clever dialogue and memorable characters.
Fanciful landscapes and imaginative enemies give Ballpoint Universe Infinite lots of quirky appeal.
Terraria Vita is the best version of an already amazing game because you can take this enthralling adventure with you wherever you go.
9.03m tries to stir your emotions, but its attempts to honor the dearly departed are weightless.
Violett channels Salvador Dali and Tim Burton in a surreal and challenging tale.
Max: The Curse of Brotherhood is pretty, and pretty decent.
Halo: Spartan Assault transfers adequately from mobile platforms to the Xbox One, with microtransactions in tow.
Flow remains a beautifully simple blueprint for the developer's later triumphs.
X Rebirth's endless deficiencies make it an inferior husk of the X games that came before it.
New content may be light in this add-on, but State of Decay: Breakdown ramps up the emphasis on survival.
NES Remix may bring back fond memories if you've played the games it features, but it doesn't actually capture what made some of those games great in the first place.
The combat in Strength of the Sword is impressive and challenging, but boring enemies and a steep learning curve drag things down.
Saint Seiya: Brave Soldiers slathers lots of fan service over a simple fighting game core.
A detour for a slave-turned-pirate-turned-assassin helps sow the seeds of a rebellion in this well-intentioned but flawed add-on.
A realistic tab-based approach to rhythm game rocking makes BandFuse: Rock Legends a wailing good time despite some tough love in the learning department.
Baldur's Gate II retains some familiar flaws, but this enhanced model is one more reason to revisit a classic role-playing game.
Speedball 2 definitely has the speed down, but the barebones multiplayer limits the fun.
All That Remains establishes characters and conflicts that may pay off in forthcoming episodes, but it doesn't stand up well on its own.
Dust 514's bid to expand the EVE universe is an exercise in ennui.
Story and voice work trump dwindling fear in Huntsman: The Orphanage.
Thanks to its excellent battle system, Bravely Default breathes new life into a traditionalist genre.
Gomo has heart, but its brevity and lack of challenge keep it from being worth your while.
The frenetic Samurai Gunn provides an exciting competitive experience that demands precision and rewards fast fingers and thoughtful strategies.
Broken Sword 5: The Serpent's Curse returns the series to its former glory with excellent storytelling and characters.
Well-constructed action and exploration make Ys: Memories of Celceta a delightful adventure.
Tiny Brains is big on personality but short on intellect.
Vector is an exciting free-running platformer that flies high.
Its problems add up quickly, but there's enjoyment in Darkout's more advanced crafting systems if you dig deeply enough into them .
Doki-Doki Universe is a simple game that uses humor and eccentricity to carry its warmhearted message.
Two Brothers seems like just another nostalgia trip, but it hides more than its share of poignant secrets.
Gran Turismo 6 celebrates the series' great legacy, but stutters toward the checkered flag.
The Novelist doesn't tell the most tightly constructed of stories, but the choices it forces you to make have real, affecting weight.
Peggle 2 is an engrossing explosion of sights, sounds, and laughs.
Adventure Time: Explore the Dungeon Because I DON'T KNOW is a terrible excuse for a dungeon crawler with nothing to offer anyone.
Dead Sky merges tower defense and zombie action into one terrible mess.
A ton of unlockable planes and exciting dogfights overshadow World of Warplanes' tendency towards repetition.
There's fast-paced fun to be had in Blacklight: Retribution, but its demanding free-to-play model dulls the sheen.
Fighter Within is a laughable attempt at a fighting game.
Super Motherload offers a peaceful respite from the cacophony of civilization.
Luxuria Superbia momentarily kindles your fire, but quickly loses energy.
EVE Online is one of the most unique and challenging MMORPGs running.
The definitive versions of Madden NFL 25 excel on subtlety.
Powerstar Golf sticks to tried-and-true methods to deliver a reliably enjoyable take on the sport.
Zoo Tycoon's animals are adorable, but a clunky interface prevents this management sim from reaching its potential.
If you're looking for on-the-go minigame mayhem, Mario Party: Island Tour is an enjoyable sojourn.
While Redshirt is a funny and clever sim that allows for interesting relationships, it can occasionally be as mindless as the social networks it parodies.
You probably won't recognize any of its crossover characters, but Aquapazza is still an engaging, fun fighter.
Ryse: Son of Rome looks the part, but underneath its pretty exterior lies a shallow, mind-numbingly tedious action game.
Improved player movement and fantastic stadium atmosphere ensure the quintessential FIFA 14 experience.
Cities of Tomorrow doesn't add much to the deeply flawed SimCity aside from Blade Runner visuals.
NBA Live 14 struggles in just about every facet, resulting in an unsatisfying and frustrating version of basketball.
Forza's love for all things fast is more infectious than ever in this exquisite racing sim.
Tearaway's blend of the real and virtual worlds makes it a rare and charming treat.
Risk of Rain brings roguelike elements to a challenging 2D platformer that glorifies the item hunt.
Killer Instinct successfully updates the '90s classic into a competitive fighter that can enter the ring with the genre's regulars.
Super Mario 3D World is a sublime platformer that's full of wonderful ideas and fabulous level design.
Deadfall Adventures is a boring, glitchy, and repetitive shooter with too few moments of clarity.
Crimson Dragon attempts to bring on-rails shooters into the modern era, but fails to recreate the genre's classic straightforward action in the process.
Its situations and story are riotous, but LocoCycle can't translate its fun humor into fun gameplay.
Dead Rising 3 has a lot of fun encouraging you to use its impressive array of barmy, brutal weaponry in an undead city.
SimCity has a lot of flaws, one of which is an extremely unrealistic depiction of what it's like to sit in a mayor's chair.
Need for Speed: Rivals smartly builds on the strong foundation of its predecessors to deliver an aggressive arcade racer that bristles with energy.
NBA 2K14 uses its incredible visual design to draw you in, and the top-notch action is closer than ever to the real thing.
It's a pleasure to exist in Morphopolis' gorgeous spaces. Making your way through them proves less inviting.
Blood of the Werewolf is a fun and challenging platformer that pays homage to Hollywood's classic movie monsters.
The Legend of Zelda: A Link Between Worlds is packed full of enough canny puzzles and clever dungeons to make the experience feel as fresh as its iconic predecessor.
Dull combat with little diversity banishes Knack to a dark realm normally reserved for the likes of foul goblins.
Sound Shapes is a singular experience that uses the power of music to elevate its enthralling platforming.
Killzone: Shadow Fall's multiplayer plays to the series' key strengths. It's too bad the campaign forgot to turn on the heat.
Flower remains a ravishing display of nature's grace.
Wonky physics and prosaic puzzles prevent Contrast from making the most of its intriguing concept and intoxicating atmosphere.
Resogun takes a classic formula and supercharges every aspect, culminating in a game that challenges your reflexes and dazzles you with its explosive presentation.
Intake is a frenetic shooter that does a great job capturing the euphoria of modern electronic music.
Final Exam provides sufficient cause to once again do everything you've already done before.
Ratchet & Clank: Into the Nexus packs a lot of joyful action and hysterical dialogue into its short running time.
BioShock Infinite's mechanics don't play nicely with the underwater city of Rapture in Burial at Sea - Episode 1.
XCOM: Enemy Within is a feature-packed expansion that makes a great game even greater.
A clever tale of a man, a pink spaghetti arm emerging from his head, and a quest for justice.
The short but sweet Journey of a Roach presents a charming postapocalyptic world.
Warface brings tons of visual shine to the free-to-play space, but this generic first-person shooter doesn't go far beyond the basics.
Where action role-playing games are concerned, Path of Exile is as good as they come.
Awful combat, persistent load times, and a host of ever-building annoyances make Valhalla Knights 3 a miserable slog.
The Guided Fate Paradox provides a near limitless amount of content. The problem is that most of it isn't all that interesting.
With an outstanding new co-op mode and a campaign fueled by fierce combat, Call of Duty: Ghosts is another great addition to the blockbuster shooter franchise.
The mobile classic comes to consoles, but at a much higher price.
The Harvest is short, forgettable, and tedious.
Mario & Sonic's latest outing has the occasional fun moment, but fails to secure a podium finish.
Castlevania: Lords of Shadow - Mirror of Fate HD improves upon the original release by upgrading the visuals and stripping out unnecessary quick-time events.
Pac-Man and the Ghostly Adventures is merely competent, but a surreal undercurrent does make you think differently about the pellet eater.
Forced offers friends a unique cooperative brawler, but only if they can connect.
There's a fun fighting system in Infinity Blade III, but it isn't enough to carry this unnecessarily bloated adventure.
Lego Marvel Super Heroes charms at every turn with its varied content and tongue-in-cheek attitude.
Easily the most ambitious Assassin's Creed game in years, Black Flag is an outstanding adventure by any standard.
Battlefield 4's diverse and deadly multiplayer battles once again deliver exhilarating action, while the single-player campaign struggles to find its footing.
Professor Layton and the Azran Legacy has some neat puzzles and some great new minigames, but fails to step outside its comfort zone.
How to Survive doesn't push any boundaries, and it ends sooner than it should, but it does have a decent amount of solid play punctuated by bursts of excellence.
Eldritch starts strong with tense gameplay and great exploration, but loses its way before the end.
WWE 2K14 sports impressive presentation that faithfully recreates the best moment in WrestleMania history, but that doesn't make the act of wrestling any more exciting.
Football Manager 2014 is the most exhaustive, most approachable entry in the series to date.
WRC 4 continues this series' regular improvements with challenging and satisfying driving, but remains a largely unremarkable off-road racer.
Batman: Arkham Origins relies much too heavily on familiar mechanics, making it a mechanically solid but uninspired adventure.
Batman's latest portable adventure falls on its face due to a bevy of design issues that are too glaring to ignore.
Solstice Arena is speedy, engaging, and terrifically fun.
Dual Destinies rises above its expected trappings to offer a witty and insightful look at the nature of truth.
140 successfully blends crisp visuals with a rhythmic soundtrack in an engaging and challenging 2D platformer.
Bionic Dues is a roguelike that looks like a rookie but plays like a pro.
There's not much new to see in Just Dance 2014, but it remains one of the most accessible and stupidly fun party games around.
There's plenty in this package, but Wii Party U's bland presentation and inconsistent game quality can take the air out of a social gaming experience.
Glare needed more substance to truly shine.
Style trumps substance in sci-fi survival horror side-scroller Dark Matter.
Iesabel gives you a cheap and quirky Diablo knockoff.
An absorbing world and minor but meaningful improvements make Deus Ex: Human Revolution - The Director's Cut a winning revival.
Rocksmith 2014 is a vast improvement on its predecessor, and a valuable learning tool for any aspiring guitar player.
The characters and intrigue of Fables are well-represented, but something is amiss in The Wolf Among Us.
Irritum blends puzzle platforming with philosophical musings, but neither element will keep you rooted in this barren world.
Grand Theft Auto V is a great game. But it too often erects roadblocks when you just want to be a catalyst for chaos.
Salvation Prophecy is a charming space sim, but it lacks gravity.
Sonic Lost World is a confused and derivative platformer that struggles to make the most of its speedy blue star.
Skylanders Swap Force is an expensive habit, but the game is so charming and fun that you'll be compelled to keep adding to your collection of cute figurines.
The Stanley Parable is simultaneously a brilliant exploration of the nature of choice in games and a wonderfully entertaining game in its own right.
Montague's Mount takes a few respectable ideas and then wholly obscures them.
Full Bore's open world of puzzles is fun to explore, though it doesn't always offer incentive to solve everything.
Blue Estate Prologue's gross humor overshadows its few merits as a game.
Knock-knock's unnerving atmosphere threatens to terrify, but there's nothing scary about its dull hide-and-seek gameplay.
Grand Theft Auto Online often rises above its troubles to become a delightfully diverse open-world escapade.
Farming meets dungeon adventuring as this Harvest Moon spin-off makes good in its first foray onto the 3DS.
League of Legends is a free-to-play multiplayer phenomenon that has cemented itself as the cornerstone of its genre.
Prime World tries to innovate on the base MOBA gameplay, but lacks soul.
Have a little patience with some of Rise of Venice’'s quirks, and you will soon enjoy forging a trading empire on the seas of the Renaissance-era Mediterranean.
Disgaea D2: A Brighter Darkness is one of the funniest and freshest role-playing games of the year.
The heavyhearted first episode of The Wolf Among Us fully cloaks you in its bloody mystery.
The beauty of BioShock Infinite is only skin deep as tedious combat and a tiresome story overshadow its artistic pleasures.
While inconsistent as a whole, The Walking Dead: 400 Days provides a few terrific snapshots into the experiences of those surviving the zombie apocalypse.
Beyond: Two Souls is a fascinating experience that expertly links story and mechanics to further your connection to the world.
In our Other Take on Disney Infinity, we look at the game from a parent's point of view and see how suitable the game is for junior players.
A.R.E.S. Extinction Agenda EX is a generally satisfying homage to a beloved action franchise.
Pokemon X and Y benefit greatly from their leap to a fully 3D world, and have plenty to offer both veterans and novices alike.
Pokemon X and Y benefit greatly from their leap to a fully 3D world, and have plenty to offer both veterans and novices alike.
Brutal robot-destroying fun is buried deep, but this giant mech battling series could still use an oil change.
Alien Rage is a generic shooter notable only for its intense difficulty.
Card Hunter's fusion of tabletop role-playing games and trading cards is easy to get into and hard to pull away from.
An extensive cast of DC characters can't help Scribblenauts Unmasked overcome the dangers posed by its own flawed internal logic.
Shadow Warrior's fiery action reaches into the past, but its sense of progression is entirely modern.
Rain uses chilling atmosphere and a heartfelt story to draw you in to this endearing adventure.
By offering further refinements to already impressive controls and animations, NBA 2K14 is one step closer to bringing the real sport to the digital world.
The original Etrian Odyssey is remade with refined customization, enchanting visuals, and an intriguing story.
F1 2013 takes you on a nostalgia trip into the history of Formula One, while compelling new modes and subtle improvements layer atop a familiar, but winning formula.
Takedown: Red Sabre is an unfinished, broken mess of a tactical shooter that offers not even one redemptive bright spot.
MechWarrior Online gets the feel of mech combat right, but its lack of variety taints the experience.
It may not be novel, but Marlow Briggs and the Mask of Death is still a boisterous and bombastic blast.
Doorways shoots for scares, but elicits yawns.
Dragon Fantasy Book II is a pale shadow of the Super Nintendo role-playing games that it is inspired by.
FIFA 14 is an exercise in subtle refinements and clever tweaks that transforms the familiar into something that feels fresh, exciting, and always engaging.
It's no revolution, but Final Fantasy XIV: A Realm Reborn is a beautiful and charming online game with plenty to see and do.
Combining beat-'em-up action with randomized levels and loot, Legend of Dungeon offers just enough variety to stem the tide of repetitive gameplay.
Killzone: Mercenary is a standard but enjoyable shooter and one of the best-looking games on the Vita.
PES 2014 moves ever closer towards simulation, and in doing so forgets exactly what makes the series so different and so much fun in the first place.
The Legend of Zelda: Wind Waker HD is a lovingly updated version of a timeless, though flawed, adventure.
It's hardly foul, but good ideas and charming animations aren't enough to save Foul Play from repetition.
ARMA III delivers sprawling geography, intense online military engagement, and a dedicated community. Just be prepared to give as much as you take.
Grand Theft Auto V is an outrageous, exhilarating, sometimes troubling crime epic that pushes open-world game design forward in amazing ways.
SteamWorld Dig is a charming, atmospheric exploration adventure, but it grinds to a halt just when it starts going full steam.
NHL 14 adds little of note to NHL 13 aside from better hitting, more fighting, and a disappointing NHL 94 retro mode.
NHL 14 adds little of note to NHL 13 aside from better hitting, more fighting, and a disappointing NHL 94 retro mode.
The Ultimate Edition of Castlevania: Lords of Shadow breathes new life into the three-year-old game through improved graphics and extra content.
The Kingdom Hearts HD 1.5 Remix compilation makes beautiful magic, but is still flawed in familiar places.
Diablo III's captivating cooperative loot-driven gameplay makes the transition to console intact.

Amnesia: A Machine for Pigs is extremely disturbing, more than a little disgusting, and impossible to stop playing.
KickBeat is a plucky new contender in the rhythm gaming arena, with punishing difficulty and pumping industrial beats.
Wildly imaginative and brimming with style, Puppeteer is a fantastic platformer that's heaps of fun for kids and adults alike.
Total War: Rome II turns the battlefields of Ancient Europe into an engrossing strategic theater.
Rhythm fans will find a lot of music, challenge, and customization to love as they get to know Hatsune Miku: Project Diva F.

Outlast is a weapons-free survival horror adventure that elicits frequent bouts of dread.

Simple, satisfying gameplay and Disney-quality art make Castle of Illusion a remake worth exploring.
The strange and delightful Rayman Legends offers a dizzying adventure whose only low point is in the few touch-screen stages.
Race the Sun is an elegant endeavor, pairing slick action and stiff challenge with systems that make you want to come back day after day.
Flashback is a great-looking remake of a classic game, but playing it is an exercise in confusion and frustration.
Its tense missions retain the spirit of the board game, but Space Hulk is ultimately a disappointing take on the Games Workshop classic.
Major improvements to the cooperative mode coupled with the Vita's portability make this the best version of the already excellent Spelunky.
Tales of Xillia is a gorgeous and fast-paced Japanese role-playing game that suffers from a few questionable design choices.
Lost Planet 3 is both less exasperating and less diverse than its predecessors.

Payday 2 brings crime to life with an alluring intensity that entertains in spite of some rough edges.

Divekick's single-player game is lacking, but this two-button brawler turns into feet-flying fun with friends.

It delivers some enjoyable stretches of shooting action, but The Bureau: XCOM Declassified too often transforms the series' signature tension into tedium.

Complex and rewarding strategizing makes the fourth game in the Europa Universalis dynasty shine.
The Brigmore Witches is a haunting end to the Dishonored story arc.
Awkward controls and other flaws make it hard to appreciate the innovative and devious puzzles in Open Me.

The Wonderful 101 is a bright, bold adventure that occasionally struggles to control its big ambitions.
With excellent writing and remarkable attention to period detail, Gone Home turns the process of exploring a house into a captivating and deeply poignant journey of discovery.
As Spelunky makes its way to the PC, the rewards and dangers are just as alluring as they were one year ago.
Beatbuddy is an adept fusion of music and gameplay.
Saints Row IV's crazy missions, fun superpowers, and funny writing make it an enjoyable way to live out your destructive fantasies.

In the cute and clever Cubetractor, simple mechanics give rise to fiendishly difficult situations.

Poor optimization and a slog of a single-player campaign hobble this fast-paced shooter.

Shadowrun Returns is a pleasant role-playing game with a potent setting.

Cloudberry Kingdom is a wonderfully challenging platformer with exciting level design and great game-changing power-ups.
Like the guards you must sneak past in this vampire stealth game, it's best to avoid Dark entirely.
The Raven: Legacy of a Master Thief superficially resembles many a classic mystery, but doesn't have the intrigue or the soul.
El Diablo's Domain brings three new costumes and a series of challenges to Guacamelee that will push even expert players to their limits.

Dota 2 is complicated, exhausting, and sometimes cruel, but its many complexities form an incredibly satisfying and exciting multiplayer game.

NCAA Football '14 is still enjoyable on the field, but conjures a strong "been there, done that" feeling.

Scourge: Outbreak is all kinds of awful.
Motorbike is a cruel joke of a game that no PlayStation 3 owner should ever consider.
Wargame: AirLand Battle is a rewarding tactical real-time strategy game that is both complex and addictive.
Leisure Suit Larry: Reloaded brings things back with an HD touch-up and a new girl, but it could have benefited from some additional refinement.

Hotline Miami is an intoxicating celebration of violence that will have you pounding the restart button for more.

Two of Capcom's best arcade beat-'em-ups get HD ports worthy of their heritage, providing a good, if easy, co-op experience.
State of Decay is an immersive and suspenseful open-world zombie adventure that shouldn't be missed.

Spying, puzzles, and acrobatic feats make Gunpoint a delight to play, but the overall experience is unfortunately short.

Fallen Enchantress: Legendary Heroes hits the sweet spot for this continually improving strategy franchise.

Streets of Rage 2 stands as one of the most well-crafted beat-'em-ups ever, and it still looks, sounds, and plays beautifully.
Resident Evil 4's strong gameplay somehow manages to survive, despite a lazy porting job that will leave some PC owners wondering what all the fuss was about.
Imprecise controls, shoddy level design, and bland characters spell doom for Death Jr.'s latest adventure.
What Blazing Lazers lacks in subtlety, it makes up for with sheer orgiastic firepower.
Replacing a light gun with touch-screen support doesn't make up for Touch the Dead's contrived gameplay or its stiff, boxy presentation.
Innocent Life is a watered-down Harvest Moon game without the series' trademark depth and charm.
Shrek the Third is a lazy game that coasts by on the strength of the brand.
Shrek the Third is a lazy game that coasts by on the strength of the brand.
Shrek the Third is a lazy game that coasts by on the strength of the brand.
Infernal embraces style over substance, resulting in a dull and repetitive shooting experience.
Heatseeker isn't a good game, but it can at times be fun in spite of its many shortcomings.
Mighty Bomb Jack is a repetitive, broken side-scroller that was somehow popular for a few months in 1987.
SBK '07 is a good mix of simulation and arcade-style racing, and it's a welcome change of pace from the Moto GP series of racing games.
Any way you slice it, Soltrio Solitaire isn't worth its price tag.
Ninja Spirit is a solid side-scrolling ninja romp and one of the TurboGrafx-16's most visually intense games.
Though it doesn't take full advantage of the PlayStation 3 hardware, MLB 07: The Show is a great game, and the new road to the show mode is fantastic.
Extreme difficulty be damned, Ninja Gaiden is still an excellent side-scrolling adventure that stands the test of time.
As the second game in the G.U. trilogy, Reminisce is content to simply fill in the gap between the first and third game in the series.
Driver '76 is a GTA clone that's technically uneven and short on originality, personality, and content.
This is a solid rendition of Pac-Man, but considering how many other ways there are to play Pac-Man out there, it's not your best choice.
Theatre of War makes World War II real-time strategy seem fresh, with outstanding attention to detail and realistic battlefields.
Tony Hawk's Downhill Jam is a passable but unexciting racing game that substitutes the finesse of the other Tony Hawk games for simple and scattered action.
After a few hours with Made Man, you'll be begging for someone to put two in the back of your head.
Rampart is a classic arcade game, but severe control issues prevent it from translating well to the PlayStation 3.
Spider-Man 3 is a slick beat-'em-up that uses the touch screen in ways that actually enhance the experience of playing the game.
Spider-Man 3 isn't anything special, but it's a solid 2D action game that lets you cut loose with Spidey's abilities.
An X-COM clone that falls short of its inspiration, UFO: Extraterrestrials is only for desperate diehards.
The Lord of the Rings Online is a fun and accessible online role-playing game that does just enough to distinguish itself from its high-profile competition.
The only thing devilish about this overblown Breakout clone is its crummy collision detection.
Double Dragon for the Xbox Live Arcade will provide some quick entertainment for nostalgia fiends, but the game doesn't hold up as well as you might hope.
ArmA is a challenging and immersive game of modern warfare, but one packed with plenty of frustrating moments and flaws, as well.
This isn't the best version of Final Fight you could be playing, but in a pinch, even a compromised version of one of the best brawlers ever made will do.
Performance and control issues make the PC version of Spider-Man 3 more problematic than its Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3 counterparts.
Tedious gameplay, poor vehicle handling, and an unfriendly interface are just a few reasons why you should leave this game in the bargain bin.
Castlevania's great atmosphere and solid action will keep you playing despite the punishing difficulty.
Ordyne is an unremarkable shoot-'em-up that pales in comparison to all of the other shooters that are available on the Virtual Console.
Command & Conquer 3 on the Xbox 360 is an excellent game and a great example of how a console RTS should work.
7 Wonders is a competent clone of a competent Bejeweled clone that does little to set itself apart.
SNK vs. Capcom Card Fighters DS is an often entertaining game, which makes its shoddy production and localization especially disappointing.
Th3 Plan is about as clever as representing letters with numbers.
The Wii version of Spider-Man 3 is a depressing combination of ugly to look at and dull to play.
The PlayStation 2 version of Spider-Man 3 is a depressing combination of ugly to look at and dull to play.
This is, at best, a step sideways for the Spider-Man movie games.
This is, at best, a step sideways for the Spider-Man movie games.
Despite spending years on the shelf, The Red Star ably delivers a unique and challenging blend of beat-'em-up and top-down shooter action.
More refined controls would have made Super Rub a Dub less frustrating, but that wouldn't be enough to make it worthwhile.
Gauntlet II is a faithful port of the arcade original, but the single-player mode isn't much fun and the presentation is bare bones.
Penumbra is loaded with creepy psychological horror that really gets under your skin.
Wonder Boy in Monster World is a 2D adventure with some nice role-playing nuances and a whole bunch of charm.
Shockman doesn't give you as many weapons or explosions as some other run-and-gun action games, but it's decent nonetheless.
This interpretation of the classic board game isn't going to be accessible to everyone, but those willing to learn it will find the gameplay immensely satisfying.
Heatseeker isn't a good game, but it manages to be fun in spite of its many shortcomings.
Heatseeker isn't a good game, but it manages to be fun in spite of its many shortcomings.
The goofy charm of Legend of the Mystical Ninja is hampered by its uneven gameplay.
Centipede and Millipede were arcade classics, but bad control and lame "evolved" modes make this package a stinker.
The only thing the Wii version of Bionicle Heroes brings to the table is another reason not to play this game.
Cube's decent premise is diluted by its dull visuals and uninspired puzzles.
This is an accurate version of Virtua Fighter 2 for the Sega Genesis, but why would anyone actually want to play Virtua Fighter 2 for the Sega Genesis?
Episode 6 ends Sam & Max season one on a high note by maintaining the great sense of humor and good puzzle design that you've seen in previous installments.
Don't expect any grand, over-the-top treatment of Spartan history, as Sparta: Ancient Wars is a very generic real-time strategy game.
This arcade tank shooter delivers lots of explosions, but proves that you can have too much of a good thing even when you're blowing stuff up.
Calling All Cars! is a frantic good time that's cut short by a serious lack of content.
The sequel to Generation of Chaos provides more of the same strategic gameplay without doing anything to correct the problems with the original.
Rayman Raving Rabbids is a fairly simple collection of minigames that manages to win you over largely on the merit of its personality.
Aside from the name, this street racer has little to distinguish itself from an already crowded field.
While F.E.A.R. is still a good action game, it doesn't live up to its potential, thanks to stuttering frame rates and washed-out graphics.

Battle Lode Runner is good news for anyone hoping to see other Japan exclusives in the North American Virtual Console shop, but that's about it.
Controls that fluctuate between touchy and unresponsive, very few game modes, and lousy multiplayer all conspire to bring down Bust-A-Move Bash!
Unless you're already a huge Gyruss fan, this isn't a must-own Xbox Live Arcade download.
Dragon's Curse might not be a classic, but it is fun while it lasts.
The novelty of the Vietnam War setting is just about all that Whirlwind Over Vietnam has going for it.
Diamond and Pearl do what the Pokémon franchise has always done best--deliver an accessible and highly addictive role-playing game experience.

Air Battles: Sky Defender makes for a solid introduction to the flight combat genre for newer players, and the price is right too.

Disney's Meet the Robinsons is a fairly satisfying movie tie-in that borrows heavily from a number of classic adventure and action games.

After a few hours with Made Man, you'll be begging for someone to put two in the back of your head.

There's not an awful lot of game here, but flOw still makes for an attractive and soothing showpiece.
