Virtua Fighter 5 builds upon VF4 with new moves and characters, making for a great sequel.
Sonic and the Secret Rings delivers an excellent sense of speed and plenty of depth, and what's just as impressive is that it makes Sonic fun again.
Deep on gameplay but light on content, NBA Street Homecourt's Xbox 360 debut is ultimately a great one.
Maelstrom can't even get the basics right, and the few features that sound interesting on paper end up being completely useless.
Experienced role players will enjoy the engaging combat and diplomatic gameplay, in spite of Vanguard's litany of bugs and singular focus on group adventuring.
Kirby's Adventure is a charming platformer that holds up because it isn't just another Super Mario clone.
Whether you're playing alone or with a friend, Ice Climber is still challenging and fun.
Thanks to the Virtual Console, a new generation can experience the simple gameplay and cruel levels contained in Kid Icarus.
Brutal difficulty is the only thing that sets this WWII real-time strategy game apart from its predecessors.
Ghost Rider steals liberally from several major action games, yet somehow avoids stealing the parts that made those games fun.
Ghost Rider steals liberally from several major action games, yet somehow avoids stealing the parts that made those games fun.
You've already got at least a couple of shooters on your hard drive far better than this one.
Few of the nine minigames that make up Wii Play have much staying power.
With a lengthy, engaging story, great production values, and loads of interesting gameplay touches, this is an action adventure game that's worth the challenge.
If you ever cared about the arcade version of Paperboy, you'll get some nostalgic excitement from this emulation of the original.
Juka's quest is aesthetically pleasing and has some twists on the usual action RPG blueprint, but the easygoing gameplay is clearly geared toward younger players.
Final Fantasy VI Advance is a great port of an excellent role-playing game, and it's one that shouldn't be missed.
A few translation imperfections aside, this is the same great beat-'em-up from 2005. If you never had a chance to play it on consoles, it's still well worth it.
The new pitching mechanic breathes some new life into the aging but still very good MVP Baseball franchise.
When Origin of the Species isn't breaking your mind with its insane storyline and terrible gameplay, it's probably breaking itself with one of its many, many bugs.
Crackdown creates an exciting open world and gives you a lot of cool abilities, but there isn't enough main-game content to truly take advantage of these elements.
Despite the game's lackluster visuals, budding paleontologists and Pokémon fans alike should find an enjoyable romp through time in this DS adventure.
This is an enhanced version of 2004's Starshatter that adds improved AI and production values, but that's about it.
Konami's seminal football game finally makes its way to the Xbox 360, but it doesn't fulfil many next-generation ambitions.
Konami's sixth Pro Evolution Soccer title plays a superb game of football but offers little in the way of new features.
Even the promise of blowing away the most generic of terrorists in Middle America isn't enough to make Patriots anything more than a rote, mind-numbing shooter.
It's surprising that Hudson has gone to the trouble of making such a terrible beat-'em-up available for the Wii's Virtual Console.
Soldier Blade is a solid shoot-'em-up that keeps you busy with a steady outpouring of large enemy ships and accompanying gunfire.
This is a great, cheap way to get your hands on an underappreciated arcade classic.
All of the flaws that make Ecco so frustrating were easier to tolerate back when the concept was new and the graphics were leading edge. No such luck in 2007.
Ar tonelico is built on a solid role-playing foundation, but the lengthy character exchanges and lack of any challenge take a lot of the fun out of the game.
Unless you already own this game on one platform or another, or just hate fun, there's no reason not to download Super Mario World.
Though not as expansive a collection as the title might suggest, Capcom Puzzle World is worth the price of admission for Super Puzzle Fighter II Turbo alone.
The Burning Crusade is a superb example of exactly what an expansion pack for any game should be.
A lousy conversion of the anime's story, as well as some equally poor beat-'em-up action, keeps the golden shine out of Fullmetal Alchemist on the DS.
Diddy Kong Racing DS is an OK racer with plenty to do, but the ridiculous number of tasks you have to do to enjoy all of it may irritate those ...
Sonic the Hedgehog may share its name with the Genesis original, but this game is even more broken than most of the other recent Sonic games have been.
Contra III: The Alien Wars is every bit the vexing challenge it was back in the '90s, and it's still quite a bit of fun too.
Underground Pool is a squalid representation of the game of billiards.
Fans of Bubble Bobble, puzzle games, dinosaurs, or fun will be sorely disappointed.
Bionicle Heroes for the GBA is a slick run-and-gun shoot-'em-up.
Although it lacks online play, Bionicle Heroes is a surprisingly adept and enjoyable first-person shooter.
Neither quality fan service nor a good action game on its own merits, The Shield fails miserably to live up to its license's pedigree.
Battlestations: Midway strikes just the right balance between action and strategy to create a game that's as unique as it is enjoyable.
Battlestations: Midway strikes just the right balance between action and strategy to create a game that's as unique as it is enjoyable.
A Link to the Past is still great, and it hasn't been rereleased to death like some of Nintendo's other games, making it a great choice for Virtual Console fans.
Comix Zone is a mediocre beat-'em-up that's supported by a unique gimmick.
It's a shame that Arthur and the Invisibles on the GBA can't just take after its namesake and disappear.
Its minigame format is a well-worn one, but the inclusion of online play in Fuzion Frenzy 2 gives the game an edge.
A date with Kim Jong II would be more enjoyable than this shooter.
The captivating PSP version of this classic PC strategy game captures all the charming fun of being a pirate of the Caribbean.
Rafa Nadal Tennis isn't a good game, but it's not the worst tennis game available for the Nintendo DS.
Legend of Heroes III is a competent and lengthy role-playing game, but it's painfully generic without the slightest tinge of originality or creative flair.
As the title advertises, Crashday has a fair number of car crashes, but the trouble is that it doesn't have much of anything else.
Sam & Max's third episode feels shorter than the previous two, and at least part of that is due to so many of the environments being recycled from previous episodes.
The rapid-fire minigames found in Arthur and the Invisibles offer a different take on the WarioWare style of play, and they're fun for the short time the game lasts.
It's as deep and broad as you would expect from a great strategy game, but Europa Universalis III's most notable achievement is how easy it is to get into.
Digimon World DS is a solid, if unremarkable monster battle game, which pretty much means it's the best Digimon game ever made.
Take this deal and you'll be out $20 and minutes of your life you'll never get back.
If you have the misfortune of playing Mini RC Rally, you can at least find solace in knowing the next game you play won't be any worse.
While the original R-Type offers more precise action, R-Type III has bigger boss fights, better graphics, and a more forgiving learning curve.
While the original R-Type offers more precise action, R-Type III has bigger boss fights, better graphics, and a more forgiving learning curve.
Because of its high production values, fans of the movie may enjoy this movie tie-in, but the epic scope of the adventure is hampered by the unoriginal gameplay.
Xiaolin Showdown has its problems, but it's generally a solid beat-'em-up.
Like an anime version of Star Wars, this big, lavishly produced action RPG is another good reason not to shelve your PlayStation 2 just yet.
Hotel Dusk weaves an absorbing noir-style mystery with traditional adventure game elements and stylish presentation and does it all with a deft touch.
The sheer number of cars and tracks in Micro Machines V4 doesn't make up for the underlying frustration of the racing.
This is a lot like last year's game, except now instead of 06, it says 07 on the box.
Whether you remember ToeJam & Earl or not, this is a good, solid two-player game that's worth checking out.
Eragon doesn't do much to embellish its simplistic design, but it's a surprisingly satisfying role-playing game despite its shortcomings.
Beneath numerous flaws there's a decent basketball game in March Madness 07, but you've got to dig too deep to find it.
Neither quality fan service nor a good action game on its own merits, The Shield fails miserably to live up to its license's pedigree.
Drive to Survive will make you want to do neither.
The cute creatures with suicidal tendencies are as appealing as ever, but without the features of the PSP version, Lemmings for the PS3 loses some of its appeal.
It isn't the best version of Street Fighter II, but World Warrior is still easily the best fighting game available so far on the Wii--Virtual Console or otherwise.
Gradius represented a significant step in the evolution of the shooter, and though its boss battles can be frustrating, much of the experience still stands up.
Moto Roader is fun when played with friends, but as a single-player experience it's a drag.
The PC version of Raving Rabbids is still a goofy collection of minigames, but some of the fun was lost in translation from the Wii.
Heavy Weapon's arcade-style shooting is incredibly appealing, especially when you get into the ridiculous action in the multiplayer modes.
This simplistic brawler's condescending attitude and one-note gameplay make it worth dodging.
This simplistic brawler's condescending attitude and one-note gameplay make it worth dodging.
Avatar on the PSP is a solid hack-and-slash that will likely appeal to fans of the show as well as anyone that has enjoyed similar games in the past.
The Avatar's DS debut serves up an engaging story and some slick 3D visuals, but it's otherwise just another mediocre brawler.
Although it doesn't break any new ground, the Avatar's foray on the GBA is a lively action adventure that offers a solid mix of combat and puzzles.
Justice for All is a good, lengthy adventure with great character-driven storylines, but it fails to build upon the promising groundwork laid by the first game.
Situation: Comedy stands on its own, but it isn't quite as good as the previous episode of the Sam & Max series.
Rayman Raving Rabbids on the GBA returns the titular hero to his platforming roots, but the game is so rote and uninteresting that it's hard to care all that much.
Ironically, while this penguin-themed puzzle game seems geared toward younger players, it may be too challenging for the average kid.
Ironically, while this penguin-themed puzzle game seems geared toward younger players, it may be too challenging for the average kid.
The Wii and WarioWare are a perfect match.
Lost Planet: Extreme Condition makes shooting giant bugs every bit as fun as it should be, and even though it ends too quickly, you'll have a blast while it lasts.
Are you dying to play some more Ms. Pac-Man? If so, then pick this up, but keep in mind that it's a very barebones emulation of the original game.
It's a decent brawler, but repetitive combat and missions keep it from rising above the level of Naruto fan service.
One of the best early Castlevania games is available on the Virtual Console, and it still packs a decent bite.
If you missed it the first time around, now is your chance to check out one of the best puzzle games for the Nintendo Entertainment System.
Urban Champion was barely passable 20 years ago, so you can probably guess that it hasn't aged especially well.
Dr. Robotnik's Mean Bean Machine is a fun little puzzle game that's just not quite worth the price of admission.
Mazes of Fate has a great premise and some interesting ideas, but it never leaves the trappings of the old-school dungeon crawlers it's based on.
The breakneck action of SNK's playfully over-the-top military shooter series still holds up, despite compromised motion controls and additional load times.
If you didn't like GripShift on the PSP this version won't change your mind, but it might be worth a look for anyone who hasn't played this driving/platform game.
Swordcraft Story 2 sticks to the basics to deliver an easily enjoyable role-playing game that doesn't take itself too seriously.
The half-baked American Idol trappings don't detract from this otherwise solid iteration of Konami's long-lived karaoke series.
Simbin follows up its GTR 2 success with another great PC racing sim, this time set in the World Touring Car series.
Like so many of the early NES sports games, Baseball hasn't withstood the test of time.
Online Chess Kingdoms is predictably unsuccessful in its attempts to enhance the timeless classic, but thankfully it does let you play classic chess online or off.
BattleZone is fun for the couple of hours it takes to finish, but it's over too quickly.
Super Mario Bros. is still totally sweet, even after more than 20 years.
New Rally-X wasn't a terribly exciting game when it was released in 1981, so it's tough to get worked up about an arcade-perfect version of it 25 years later.
Desperate Housewives isn't much of a game, but it does a pretty good job of telling an original, interactive soap opera story in the quirky tone of the hit show.
Sports Interactive's best title to date combines stability and variety in an immersive football experience.
Sports Interactive slims down its PC hit so you can scratch the football management itch wherever you are.
Novadrome offers a glossy-looking take on the tried-and-true concept of futuristic car combat, but fails to do anything interesting or noteworthy with it.
FIFA Manager 07 is a beautifully presented and accessible football management game that's tailored for novices of the genre.
Far Cry Vengeance tries to blend recycled content with new gameplay designed for the Wii, but the results are lackluster across the board.
Blazing Angels' very straightforward campaign and barren online play don't add up to make a particularly engaging air combat game.
Overtime is an apt subtitle for this port of Blitz: The League, as the exceedingly lengthy load times and sluggish running speed run the game well past regulation.
It takes a while to shift into high gear, but once it does, Star Wars: Lethal Alliance offers an enjoyable mix of shooting, puzzle-solving, and platforming.
Brothers in Arms D-Day is based on a couple of great tactical shooters, but it suffers crippling losses in translation from consoles to the PSP.
Cruddy hit detection and poor hazard placement ruin this otherwise decent action romp.
Variety and slick presentation go a long way toward making you forget about the lack of originality and the quest's brief length.
Super Star Soldier is a relic of the days when gruelingly difficult deep-space shoot-'em-ups were as common as today's first-person shooters.
The PS2 version of this military shooter addresses some of the issues that hampered its 2-year-old PC counterpart, but it introduces far more problems than it fixes.
This is a perfect port of the NES version of Donkey Kong Jr.--all four levels of it.
Revolutions does a nice job of fixing up Victoria, but it's more of a giant patch than an expansion.
Star Trek Legacy for the Xbox 360 captures the grandeur and feel of the epic starship battles in the famous television series.
Gunstar Heroes became a definitive run-and-gun action game when it was first released in 1993, and its quirky personality and nonstop intensity still shine through.
The highlight of Bomberman Land Touch! is the excellent battle mode that supports as many as four players online and as many as eight offline.
The Virtual Console breathes new life into this obscure, but very good, pinball game.
As the first poker game for the Wii, World Series of Poker is serviceable, though the lack of online play and lackluster presentation don't help its cause.
Tennis can be entertaining for a little while, but it's difficult to recommend when there's a much better option available in Wii Sports' tennis game.
Luxor: The Wrath of Set's uninteresting gameplay and lackluster presentation don't do anything to set it apart from other, better puzzle games available for the PSP.
Brutal difficulty makes Silent Heroes suitable solely for the squad-based real-time strategy experts.
A simple shoot-'em-up that looked flashy for its time, Space Harrier II is a reminder of how sequels aren't always as good as their predecessors.
No amount of Xzibit influence or ride pimpage can save Pimp My Ride from its god-awful minigames and lousy driving mechanics.
No amount of Xzibit influence or ride pimpage can save Pimp My Ride from its god-awful minigames and lousy driving mechanics.
This old Tetris-inspired puzzler wasn't very special back when it was first released in 1990, and that aspect of it hasn't aged a bit.
Even kids who loved the animated film won't find Happy Feet to be worth their time.
Even kids who loved the animated film won't find Happy Feet to be worth their time.
The Ant Bully on the Wii is basically the same uninteresting mess that came out for the GameCube six months earlier.
The younger crowd may find Cartoon Network Racing to be an enjoyable racer featuring familiar and likable characters, but anyone else likely won't be as enamored.
This derivative kart racer is no fun for the entire family.
Dominions 3 is a complex, deep, and incredibly rich strategy game that will reward those willing to invest in it with an almost unlimited variety of play.
Platypus is a simplistic, short-lived shoot-'em-up with visuals and gameplay that are adequate rather than impressive.
The Sims 2: Pets for the PSP might have been a decent port of the console versions, if it would've just stopped loading for a second.
Happy Feet on the DS is oriented around sledding and tap-dancing. Neither aspect is any good.
Cute penguins and dance segments similar to those found in Konami's Dance Dance Revolution are the high points of this game that's based on an animated movie.
The follow-up to a tile-flipping puzzle game for the Nintendo DS features a simple, challenging design that makes up for a bare-bones presentation.
Rainbow Six is reinvented and reinvigorated for a new age thanks to beautiful visuals and top-notch tactical shooting action.
This hybrid of a shooter and hide-and-go-seek works best as a demonstration for what the Wii's motion sensing technology--though it's not a half bad game, either.
Ultramix 4 has all of the modes you'd expect from a DDR game, but whether or not any of that is worthwhile depends on how you feel about the song ...
College Hoops 2K7 is a good college basketball game, but it's nearly identical to College Hoops 2K6.
Despite cramming in a respectable amount of licensed material, weak minigames and a plodding pace mean this ship bilges on its anchor.
Despite cramming in a respectable amount of licensed material, weak minigames and a plodding pace mean this ship bilges on its anchor.
This movie-licensed World War I dogfighter takes off, stalls, and nosedives straight into the ground.
Twilight Princess contains the same expertly designed puzzles and gameplay that you've come to expect, though parts of its presentation feel stuck in the past.
An alternative to the blueprint for strategy role-playing games, Yggdra Union is strange, complicated, interesting, and charming.
Super Swing offers a quirky experience that may strike a chord with some players, but will probably turn off anyone looking for a traditional round of golf.
The motion controls don't fundamentally change this movie-licensed platformer, but they don't get in the way either, and the adventure is still a breezily fun one.
While the motion-sensitive controls don't fully justify the Wii version's higher price tag, they do make a fun sandbox game seem even more engaging.
Eragon has some exciting moments, but they are overshadowed by frustrating controls and tedious level designs.
Full Auto 2 is technically proficient, but almost every aspect of this car combat game's gameplay is messed up in one way or another.
This starship combat game simply can't overcome bad controls, frustrating mission designs, and a mess of bugs.
Assault Heroes takes several cues from the great arcade shooters of the '80s and '90s but manages to spin all of these influences into a unique-feeling product.
Fans of sluggish frame rates and clichéd combat racers pay attention: Pocket Racers is the game for you.
Battle of Atluma gets the WarCry card-game mechanics down cold. Unfortunately, the chill permeates every aspect of the presentation.
SingStar's American debut presents a decent song list and sparse but functional game modes that amount to a reasonably entertaining karaoke package.
Ice Hockey is almost every bit as fun now as it was in 1988.
Mercury Meltdown Remix is a handheld puzzler that feels ill suited for the PS2, but because the underlying puzzle designs are so good, the game still mostly works.
Eragon is short and the touch-screen controls don't work very well, but it's still a fairly decent action adventure game.
EA Replay contains a few genuine classics, but most of these 16-bit games haven't aged well, which makes them hard to come back to.
Tomb Raider: Legend offers a good mix of gunplay and puzzles; it also shows off the system's 3D capabilities.
Tomb Raider: Legend delivers a solid platforming experience that manages to mix in a healthy dose of the gunplay and puzzles that the console versions contained.
Teen Titans the game makes good use of the license to spice up what is otherwise a very average beat-'em-up.
Rayman Raving Rabbids is a fairly simple collection of minigames that manages to win you over largely on the merit of its personality.
Best suited for anyone fortunate to have played the previous game, Original Generation 2 is a great little space opera in its own right.
Capcom Classics Collection 2 isn't as hit-driven as the first game, but the hits that are present hit very hard, indeed.

History Channel: Civil War is good for a few mindless hours of shooting action, but not much else. History buffs need not apply.

Sonic Rivals keeps it simple and offers plenty of high-speed thrills, though it also has its share of frustrating moments.
Fortress of Solitude is a passable puzzler that offers a decent selection of Sudoku-style puzzles.
Superman Returns for the DS is a terrible game for numerous reasons.
The Xbox 360 has its share of poker titles, but none are as distinctly flawed as WCP: All In.
Monster Bomber isn't as complicated as some puzzlers, but its quick pace and hands-on nature are undeniably appealing.

It may not look like much, but for a budget-priced game, Corvette Evolution GT actually offers enough enjoyable racing to make it worth a look.

Fight Night Round 3 features the same great gameplay the franchise is known for as well as a few minor, but appreciable, additions exclusive to the PlayStation 3.
Capcom's latest PSP compilation has some emulation issues, but there's enough of the good stuff on the disc to make it worth checking out.

The colorful presentational coating is tasty, but unfinished features and rotten AI keep Heroes of Annihilated Empires from reaching its potential.
Burdened by clumsy controls and predictable artificial intelligence, Tenkaichi 2 is a game that can be loved only by forgiving DBZ fans.
Avatar had the potential to be an enjoyable game, but extremely repetitive and tedious gameplay mean that most of that potential went untapped.

Steering Cars with the Wii Remote works pretty nicely, but some of the minigame control schemes and a few bugs conspire to drag down this film-licensed racer.
The controller may fit the bill, but Rapala Tournament Fishing just isn't the big catch that virtual anglers were hoping for.
NRA Gun Club's awful gameplay and presentation make it an effective though unintended antigun message: Guns are boring.
This retail package containing Bethesda's downloadable content updates for its groundbreaking role-playing game gives you more quality for a budget price.
The Rise of the Witch-King is a fairly standard expansion that adds a brief campaign centered around one of the more enigmatic characters from the movies.

What SmackDown! vs. RAW 2007 improves isn't necessarily what the series actually needed to improve, but on its own merits, it's still a very good wrestling game.

Sneak King isn't a good game, but it's so crazy and so cheap that it still manages to be weirdly compelling.
Bomberman '93 is a perfect fit for the Wii's party-game mentality, and has the multiplayer support it needs to get you hooked all over again.
Golden Axe is an influential arcade classic, and the Sega Genesis version kept its intense hack-and-slash gameplay intact, so it's still fun to pick up and play.

Rush is a middling street racing game that really wasn't worth your time when it was released on consoles last year, and certainly isn't worth your time now.
It's a straightforward remake of Koei's cult-favorite rhythm game, but Gitaroo Man still knows how to rock.
Road to Respect shoehorns the Sopranos license into a clumsy, poorly designed action game that isn't the least bit enjoyable to play.
Not only is this a nicely done remake of an influential, little-seen early chapter from this long-running role-playing series, it's also an all-around solid RPG.
Echoes of Faydwer is EverQuest II's most appealing expansion yet, thanks to a new continent, a new race, and a wealth of new content to round them out.
Solomon's Key holds up surprisingly well after all these years, thanks to its interesting mix of action and puzzles.
It wasn't very good when it hit the NES in 1987, and it's even less fun in 2006.
Activision Hits Remixed has a lot of great, old 2600 games in it, and it's selling for a nice, low price.
Subtitle or not, this ain't the second coming of Jagged Alliance.
Even those who only own a GameCube should probably avoid this version of Double Agent, which has fewer features and worse graphics than on other platforms.

Call of Duty 3 isn't just another first-person shooter that takes place during World War II. It's a fantastic game with great online play and top-notch sound.
SimCity is one of those true classics that remain fun and addictive years after their original release.
This is a perfect emulation of Pinball. But Pinball wasn't a very good game, even when it was brand-new.
The developer behind Lumines and Meteos brings more of its trippy, trademark style, but it neglects to deliver equally compelling gameplay.
Corner Shop 2 has an appealing look and minigames that are fun at first, but the gameplay quickly wears thin because there's nothing to keep you playing.
Star Trek: Tactical Assault is a neat idea but doesn't offer much strategy--or much Star Trek.
Based on Mortal Kombat: Deception, this version gains some extra characters but little else to make it worthwhile for fans of Midway's gory fighting-game series.
New driving controls add barely a smidgen of excitement to this Wii port of a thoroughly boring monster truck racer.
Asphalt: Urban GT 2 is a fun and visually impressive arcade-style racer, even if it is just an evolutionary upgrade of the original game.
Another good thing about the Rapture is that it will take you away from disastrous, buggy games like Left Behind: Eternal Forces.
With its focus on weapon grabbing over weapon firing, Small Arms' shallow gameplay falls flat.
The newest Agatha Christie adventure game suffers from monotonous tasks and contrived plot twists that drag it down to mediocrity.
After the thrill of flying around Metropolis wears off, Superman Returns is nothing more than a below-average, repetitive movie tie-in.

Hardwood Spades is a Spades game for Spades fans, but even fans of the card game will probably be a little put off by the dull graphics and sound.
Hardwood Hearts is a Hearts game for Hearts fans. If you don't already play Hearts, you aren't likely to get much out of this one.
This budget-priced Special Edition adds some notable new features to 2005's frenetic action game, and, for better or worse, defangs its notorious difficulty level.
The strengths of Fritz 9 will likely only appeal to the most advanced chess players.
The Great Edgar Hunt is a fun platforming romp across the Warner Bros. lot for fans of the Animaniacs.
Nicktoons Unite! is too content to be another generic platformer that leans exclusively on its license.
Its overly plain presentation will probably turn off the casual set, but MVP 06 NCAA Baseball's top-notch gameplay is exactly what baseball purists are looking for.

The cheesy charm of The Brady Bunch mixes well with outrageous fighting game aesthetics, which almost compensates for the shallow gameplay.
This mobile version of this beloved fighting game series will sorely disappoint King of Fighters fans, who might reasonably expect some sort of challenge or a decent selection of characters.
WWE SmackDown! is probably the best wrestling game you could find right now for your mobile phone, but that doesn't mean it's especially good.
Most Wanted offers a lot of bells and whistles, but the core gameplay isn't any fun.
Chrome SpecForce manages to avoid going terribly awry, but it also avoids any sort of fun or excitement.
Crazy Machines is pretty similar to many other puzzle games on the PC, but the amount and quality of its content makes it worthwhile anyway.
Even if the touch-screen controls hadn't stripped away much of the subtlety of the sport, True Swing Golf would still be a lean and flavorless game of golf.
Zatch Bell!: Electric Arena captures the personality of the show, but doesn't offer much in the way of engaging gameplay.
This collection of parlor games primarily includes odds-based games like roulette and keno, which aren't all that involving.
25 to Life is a lifelessly generic shooter that, at times, feels like Max Payne without the fun.

Cuban Missile Crisis is a unique strategy game with a very cool premise and setting, though the combat itself can be a difficult mess.
Ape Escape 3 proves that more of the same isn't always a bad thing.
Slapping some of the dizzy Ape Escape energy over an easily anticipated collection of minigames makes for a mildly entertaining experience, but not a very long one.
It's good for single-sitting strategy sessions, but after you've played through the brief story once, there's no reason to ever visit Narnia again.
Underneath the religious overtones is a mediocre party game that shouldn't get much play, even at a Catholic school retreat.

Pac-Man World 3 is a platformer, characterized most notably by its fusion of classic Pac-Man moments and generic platforming gameplay.
Mutant Nightmare is a good beat-'em-up at heart, but it's totally bogged down by platforming elements, puzzles, and touch screen features that don't work, not to mention stuffy controls.
It's functional backgammon on your 360, and not much else. But if you're into the game, that's probably good enough.
Saddled with horrific controls, broken fighting mechanics, and ugly presentation, WWE Raw for mobile phones is like a steel chair to the face.
Kong: The 8th Wonder of the World is a competent action role-playing game and a decent movie tie-in.

The members of G-Unit come off as incidental in this shooting gallery-style game, which offers some nice cartoon graphics but not much in the way of exciting action.
It's highly dubious as a measurable test of your logical mind, but PQ can still be a fun, challenging puzzle game.

This watered-down imitation of the console game has some glaring problems.

Crime Life is just plain awful. Do yourself a favor and stay away from it.
Dragon Booster is a halfhearted and practically unplayable racing game with no redeeming qualities.

This tactical combat game features battles, battles, and more battles, and it's fun, though very light on content or depth.
This shoot-'em-up tries to follow in the footsteps of games like Ikaruga and Raiden, putting its own interesting-but-flawed spin on some aspects of the formula.
Spyro: Shadow Legacy is a watered-down action role-playing game that isn't challenging or engaging enough to sustain its brief campaign.
This undemanding fighter may be good enough for anime fans, but the game is too simple for fighting fans and too self-referential for anyone else.
Both games are completely devoid of gameplay, fun, and flair. Worse, they are available free for the PC.

Tecmo's long-running fighting game series hits the Xbox 360 with its best installment to date, complete with plenty of complex and interesting characters, outstandingly good visuals, and great online play.
The main character of this cleverly designed game gets to swing around using his tongue and inhale grubs and other bugs, but it's a whole lot more pleasant than that.
The storybook charm of Narnia quickly fades away, leaving a fairly average game that doesn't do much to complement the movie.
Underneath its modest looks and intimidating, complex battle system is a turn-based strategy game that is surprisingly fun and satisfying.
With so many better action adventure games available on the Game Boy Advance, this short, simplistic game is especially difficult to recommend, even for fans of the movie.
Like the other classic arcade games on Xbox Live Arcade, Robotron: 2084 remains true to its arcade roots while including great additions like online scoreboards and multiplayer.
